Graphical abstract The influence of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters on the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst was investigated by correlating their physicochemical properties with the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) activity of dibenzothiophene (DBT). The physicochemical properties of the catalysts before and after modification were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, SEM, FT-IR, H2-TPR, Py-IR, and HRTEM techniques. Results showed that the specific surface area and Lewis acid of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst were improved obviously after modification, which indicate that the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters were successfully introduced into the unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts. Besides, DBT HDS results revealed that the catalysts Z5-NiMo-10 g and Z5-NiMo-14h exhibited high hydrodesulfurization activity (the desulfurization rate of 98.1% and 100.0%, respectively). In particular, the catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g produced the highest isomerization rate of 68.9% due to more dispersed structure and suitable acidity. Keywords Unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters Surface modification Hydrodesulfurization 1 Introduction The sulfur-containing compounds and the polyaromatics in the diesel are gradually increasing due to the inferior quality of the crude oil [1–3]. And the higher polyaromatics and sulfur-containing impurities can seriously affect the combustion performance of the diesel [4,5], which can cause serious air pollution [6,7]. Thereby, all countries of the world have set more and more stringent standards for the content of sulfur-containing impurities and polyaromatics in diesel [8–10]. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and Hydrodearomatization (HDAr) are the most traditional impurity removal methods [11–14], and most of the industrialized hydrogenation catalysts can only realize simple hydrogenation for these impurities, but the proper cracking and isomerization of the hydrogenation products can't be realized. For example, the complex sulfur-containing impurities are hydrogenated to generate more cycloalkanes with benzene rings, not the simple cycloalkanes with branched chains [15,16], which can only reduce the sulfur content of the diesel, but is not favorable for the improvement of the diesel quality, so developing a bifunctional catalyst with higher hydrogenation activity and moderate cracking or isomerization performance is very necessary. The diesel hydro treating catalysts mainly include two types, supported and unsupported hydro treating catalysts [17–19], and the HDS of the complex benzothiophene impurities usually includes two different pathways, which are direct desulfurization pathway (DDS) and hydrodesulfurization pathway (HYD) [20,21], respectively. The supported catalysts are mainly based on direct desulfurization path with the main products of biphenyl (BP) and its derivatives. The pathway has higher desulfurization efficiency, but more aromatics are produced, which is not conducive to the improvement of diesel quality. However the HYD is the main reaction pathway for the unsupported hydrogenation catalyst with more products of cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) and bichlorocyclohexane (BCH), which reduce the content of aromatics, but have no great contribution to the increase of cetane number of diesel. For unsupported hydrogenation catalyst, more cycloalkanes can be produced because of higher hydrogenation activity, but the weak acidity limits its cracking and isomerization activity. So the zeolites such as ZSM-5, Y, Beta, and HMS with strong acidity were used to modify the hydrogenation catalyst to improve the acidity of hydrogenation catalyst [20,22–25]. The results showed that the acidity of the catalyst modified by zeolites was improved obviously. However, the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst was limited due to the limited loading of the active components. In addition, DDS became the main desulfurization pathway to produce more BP and its derivatives, which was difficult to be further hydrogenated deeply. Furthermore, the modified catalysts were easier to coking and deactivation because of the strong acidity of the zeolite, which is unfavorable to the stable industrial production. To improve the acidity of hydrogenation catalyst, Saheed A. Ganiyu et al. [26] synthesized the Ti-SBA-15-NiMo composite catalyst to compound the hydrogenation active component with the weak acidic Ti-SBA-15 zeolite by one-pot method. Results showed that the catalyst prepared by this method could not realize the deep hydrogenation of complex benzothiophene impurities due to its strict synthesis conditions and the difficulty of forming hydrogenation active phase, only more BP and CHB can be produced, which is unfavorable to the increase of cetane number of diesel oil. In our previous studies, the zeolite was mixed directly with the unsupported hydrogenation catalyst precursor. The results showed that the composite catalysts had lower strength and uneven acid distribution, which were not conducive to industrial application. As the secondary structure unit of the zeolite, the zeolite precursor was studied by many scholars and modified with it. Christine E. A. Kirschhock et al. [27] studied the polymerization process of MFI zeolite precursors by NMR and in situ infrared spectroscopy. The results showed that the formation of zeolite was the result of the ordered binding and growth of the zeolite precursors. P. Prokešová et al. [28,29] also studied the change of particle size of the zeolite precursors before and after hydrothermal treatment by DLS technique. The results showed that the zeolite was gradually polymerized by the zeolite primary structure unit, and found that the zeolite precursor had a very small size (nanometer level). Lukas Frunz et al. [30] encapsulated the ZSM-5 zeolite precursor into the mesoporous zeolite structure to make the zeolite precursor grow in the mesoporous structure to improve the acidity of the mesoporous zeolite. The results showed that the ZSM-5 zeolite precursor could grow into zeolite structure in the mesoporous structure, which could effectively improve the acidity of mesoporous zeolite. A novel FDU-12 mesoporous composite assembled by ZSM-5 nanoclusters was synthesized by Yuyang Li et al. [31], and the hydro treating performance for DBT and FCC diesel was studied. The results showed that the catalyst modified by ZSM-5 nanoclusters achieved the higher hydro treating activity due to its larger specific surface area and the appropriate acidic properties. Overall, the studies for zeolite nanoclusters were mainly focused on the supported catalysts, while the modification of the unsupported catalysts by nanoclusters was rarely studied. In this paper, we combined the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters with the unsupported hydrogenation catalyst to prepare the bifunctional hydrogenation catalysts with strong acidity and hydrogenation performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the catalysts The catalysts were synthesized according to the following steps [32,33], and all reagents were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company (PR China) without any further purification. Typically, 150 mL deionized water was heated to 50 °C in a flask firstly. Then the proper amount of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2 6H2O) was slowly added into the flask and stirred. When the temperature reached to 93 °C, ammonium heptamolybdate solution ((NH4)6Mo7O24 4H2O) (molar ratio Ni:Mo = 1.5) was added. When the temperature was stabilized to 93 °C, the ammonium hydroxide (28.8% NH3) was added under stirring until the solution became clear and stopped dropping, finally the pH of the clear solution was about 12, and the clear solution was further heated at 93 °C for 10 h to obtain the turbid liquid A. The turbid liquid was isolated by vacuum filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried 12 h at 100 °C and atmospheric pressure to get the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst precursor. The precursors were calcined at 350 °C for 4 h to get the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst. The obtained catalyst was labeled as NiMo-1.5. The ZSM-5 zeolite precursor was synthesized according to the previously reported conditions with some modification [34,35]. The molar composition of various raw materials was as follows: 1.0SiO2: 0.005Al2O3: 0.45TPAOH: 35H2O. In short, aluminium isopropoxide (Al(OiPr)3, 98 wt%) was dissolved in an aqueous solution of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt%) and stirred at room temperature until completely dissolved, the tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 wt%) and deionized water were added, the resulting mixture was stirred until the solution became clear again. The clear solution was added into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and crystallized at 160 °C for 10, 14, 18, and 24 h, respectively. The ZSM-5 zeolite precursor was obtained. 20 g ZSM-5 zeolite precursor with crystallization for 10, 14, and 18 h respectively were dripped into turbid liquid A to study the effect of different crystallization time. 10, 20, and 30 g (for the final modified catalyst, the acidic components accounted for 5.5%, 10.5%, and 15.0%, and the active metal content accounted for 94.5% (Ni: 56.7%, Mo: 37.8%), 89.5% (Ni: 53.7%, Mo: 35.8%), and 85.0% (Ni: 51.0%, Mo: 34.0%), respectively) ZSM-5 zeolite precursor with the crystallization time of 24 h respectively were dripped into turbid liquid A to study the effect of different amount of precursor. The mixture was stirred for overnight, and the products were filtered and washed with deionized water for many times, then the catalyst precursor powder was obtained by drying at 100 °C for 12 h. The precursor powders were tableted and then pulverized them into 20–40 mesh, calcined at 350 °C for 4 h to obtain the modified unsupported hydrogenation catalysts. The obtained catalysts were labeled as Z5-NiMo-10 h, Z5-NiMo-14 h, Z5-NiMo-18 h, Z5-NiMo-10 g, Z5-NiMo-20 g, and Z5-NiMo-30 g, respectively. 2.2 Characterization The textural and structural properties were measured by a Tristar3000 multifunctional adsorption instrument (Mike Corporation, USA). The catalysts were treated at 300 °C in vacuum to remove the gas before the measurement, and the N2 adsorption-desorption temperature was −196 °C. The FT-IR and Py-IR of all catalysts were analyzed by a Nexus infrared spectrometer (Nicolet). KBr was used as the background for the FT-IR analysis. The crystal phase of the catalysts was detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on an X’Pert Pro MPD instrument with Cu Kα. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of all catalysts was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem HP 2950 Chemisorption Analyzer (made in USA) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The morphology of the modified catalyst was observed by using a S-4800 cold field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi Company, Japan), and the morphology of the sulfurized catalyst was observed by a JEM-2100 high resolution electron transmission microscope (Hitachi Company, Japan), the average slab length (LA) and stacking layer number (NA) of MoS2 were also calculated by statistical analyses according to about 15 micrographs, including 200 slabs taken from different parts of each catalyst. The Mo atoms dispersion of the edge surface of MoS2 slabs was also calculated. The equations are as follows [36–39]: (1) L A = ∑ i = 1 t n i L i / ∑ i = 1 t n i (2) N A = ∑ i = 1 t n i N i / ∑ i = 1 t n i (3) f M o = ∑ i = 1 n ( 6 x i − 6 ) ∑ i = 1 n ( 3 x i 2 − 3 x i + 1 ) (4) L =3.2(2 x i -1)Å Where, Li is the slab length, ni of Eq. (1) presents the number of MoS2 slabs whose slab length is Li. Ni represents the stacking layer number, ni of Eq. (2) is the number of MoS2 units whose stacking layer number is Ni. And where xi is the number of atoms along one edge of a MoS2 slab determined from Eq. (4), and n is the total number of MoS2 slabs shown in the TEM micrographs. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic activities of all catalysts were evaluated using 1.0 wt% DBT in petroleum ether solution. The reactions were carried out in a fixed-bed down-flow high-pressure micro reactor (10 mm diameter and 400 mm in length) loaded with 1 mL of 20–40 mesh catalysts (bulk density is about 0.95 g/cm3) diluted with the same mesh quartz sand to 3 mL. Before reaction, the catalysts were in situ presulfided for 8 h using a 3.0 wt.% CS2/petroleum ether solution at 330 °C at a H2 pressure of 3.0 MPa and with a liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 6 h−1 and a H2/Oil ratio of 300. After that, 1.0 wt.% DBT/petroleum ether solution was pumped into the reactor as the feed with a total pressure of 3.0 MPa, with a reaction temperature of 280 °C, with a H2/Oil ratio of 300, with a liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 10 h−1, and the samples were collected after 6 h of stabilization, analyzed by a Varian 3800 gas chromatography. In addition, to estimate the selectivities of the two hydrodesulfurization routes (HYD and DDS), the following Eqs. (5) and (6) were employed [40]. The space time yield of the catalyst was calculated by the formula (7). (5) DDS = BP × 100 % THDBT+HHDBT+BP+CHB+BCH (6) HYD = ( THDBT + HHDBT + CHB + BCH ) × 100 % THDBT + HHDBT + BP + CHB + BCH (7) Y (A)= N V × Conv (A) Where, Y (A) is the space time yield of A (mol/(mL·h)), N is the moles of feed per hour (mol/h), Conv (A) represents the conversion of A, and V is the volume of catalyst (mL). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts A series of unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters with different crystallization time and amount were synthesized. The structure and morphology of the catalyst are important factor affecting its catalytic activity. In order to observe the structural changes of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters, the structure and morphology of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst before and after modification were studied by XRD and SEM. The XRD patterns of different unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1, the introduction of the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters changes the catalyst precursor from the initial crystalline state to the nearly amorphous state. The reason is that the alkalinity of the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters changes the structure of unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst precursor. In addition, for modified unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts, the weak characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 23.1° was detected, it was the characteristic peaks of the ZSM-5 zeolite microcrystals, which was possible that the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters were further crystallized after they were introduced into the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst. Fig. 2 shows the SEM diagram of unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters. The catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g is composed of some relatively small particles, the whole structure is relatively dense, and the pore distribution is more uniform. However, with the increase of the amount of zeolite nanoclusters, the structure of the catalyst becomes seriously aggregated, especially for the catalyst Z5-NiMo-30 g, the whole aggregation is more serious, which is not conducive to the formation of porous structures. For Z5-NiMo-10 h, the whole pore is like the honeycomb structure, while the pore structure of the catalyst Z5-NiMo-14 h and Z5-NiMo-18 h originates from the piling of the catalyst particles. Especially the catalyst Z5-NiMo-14 h shows a more developed pore distribution. The pore structures are also an important factor affecting catalytic activity. The higher pore volume and specific surface area are favorable for the uniform distribution of hydrogenation active site and acidic sites on the surface of the catalyst, which is beneficial to the continuous hydrogenation and isomerization reaction. The pore structure properties of unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters were detected and the results were shown in Table 1 and Fig. 3 . Table 1 shows the pore structure distribution of unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters. It is shown in the table that the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters increase significantly. And the specific surface area decreases with the increased introduction of nanoclusters. However, the pore volume and pore size show the opposite trend with the increase of the amount of nanoclusters. It is due to that some relatively small pores in the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst are occupied by the nanoclusters with the increase of the amount of nanoclusters, which reduces the number of small pores in the catalyst, thus reducing the specific surface area of the catalyst. In addition, the specific surface area of the catalyst increases firstly and then decreases with the prolongation of crystallization time, which is the result of the decomposition of the template (TPAOH) in the catalyst. The longer the crystallization time is, the more templates are encapsulated in the nanoclusters, and when the templates are decomposed by heat, more pores will be produced, which will increase the specific surface area of the catalysts. However, if the crystallization time is too long, the nanoclusters will grow into larger particles. Larger nanoparticles will destroy the pore structure of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst, thus reducing the specific surface area of the catalyst. Fig. 3 shows the pore size distribution of different unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3, the introduction of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters broadened the pore size range of unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts, and the increase of the amount of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters can expand the pore size of the catalyst, however the longer crystallization time can reduce the pore size of the catalyst, which is consistent with the results shown in Table 1. The skeleton structure and reducibility of unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters were studied by FT-IR and H2-TPR. And the results were shown in Figs. 4 and 5 . Fig. 4 shows the FT-IR spectra of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts before and after modification. The absorption bands of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts are observed at 1281, 1409, and 1600–2000 cm−1 before modification. The absorption band at 1281 cm−1 can be attributed to the Ni-O bonds, and the absorption band at 1409 cm−1 is the deformed H-N-H band for NH4 + [41,42], and the bands between 1600 and 2000 cm−1 can be assigned to the torsional vibration of the ammonium on the lattice site [41]. After modification, the absorption bands between 1200 and 1500 cm−1 almost completely disappear, indicating that the ammonium nickel moly date is easier to decompose into NiMoO4 structure after the introduction of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters. In addition, the weak absorption band at 559 cm−1 appears for the catalysts modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters, and the structure increases gradually with the increase of the nanoclusters amount and the prolongation of crystallization time. It is attributed to the five-member ring structure of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters [34,35], which is also the source of zeolite acidity. The reducibility of unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts before and after modification was studied by H2-TPR. And the results are depicted in Fig. 5. There are two different hydrogen consumption peaks at about 400 and 450 °C for all catalysts. The peak at about 400 °C represents the reduction of nickel-containing species, and the peak at about 450 °C represents the reduction of molybdenum-containing species [43,44]. Compared with the unmodified catalyst, the hydrogen consumption peaks of nickel-containing species of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts modified by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters shift to the lower temperature, while the hydrogen consumption peaks of molybdenum-containing species move to the higher temperature, which indicate that the introduction of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters enhances the reducibility of nickel-containing species but decreases the reducibility of molybdenum-containing species. The active components of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst were dispersed by ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters, which distributed more n nickel-containing species to the surface of the catalyst which was conducive to the improvement of its reducibility. In addition, the FT-IR results showed that the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst precursors were easier to decompose into NiMoO4 structure after the introduction of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters, so the interaction between nickel-containing and molybdenum-containing species were enhanced, which would reduce the reducibility of molybdenum-containing species. 3.2 Catalytic activity and acid properties The catalytic activity of unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst before and after modification was studied by DBT HDS, and the product distributions were analyzed by GC–MS. In addition, the acid properties of the catalyst are related to its isomerization or cracking activity. Suitable Lewis acid and Brønsted acid can produce high isomerization and cracking activity, respectively. To study the effect of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters on the acidity of unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst, the acid changes of unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst before and after modification were studied by Py-IR, and the results were shown in Fig. 6 and Table 3. Table 2 gives the distribution of DBT hydro desulfurization products over different unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts. The DBT conversion of the catalyst decreases with the increase of zeolite nanoclusters and increases first and then decreases with the prolongation of crystallization time. In addition, for the proportion of isomerization products (ICHB and IBCH), all catalysts have the smaller proportion than unmodified unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst (33.8%) except for the catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g (68.9%), and the Z5-NiMo-10 g has also the higher IBCH than NiMo-1.5, indicating that the Z5-NiMo-10 g has the highest isomerization activity in all catalysts. The isomerization activity of the catalyst is related to its acidity, the suitable acidity can produce higher isomerization activity. As shown in Fig. 6 and Table 3, all catalysts have only Lewis acid sites but no Brønsted acid sites, the reason is that the Brønsted acid of zeolite nanoclusters is weaker than zeolite, a small number of zeolite nanoclusters may be distributed inside the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst which could not be detected by Py-IR, and it is also possible that the Brønsted acid sites of the zeolite nanoclusters may be destroyed in the process of the reaction. The Lewis acid sites of the modified unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts were significantly enhanced after the introduction of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters, thus its isomerization activity was improved. However, with the increase of the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters, more active sites of unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst were covered by the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters, which decreased the hydrogenation performance of the catalysts, at the same time, the isomerization activity of the catalyst was also limited. For example, for the catalyst Z5-NiMo-14 h, although it produced higher DBT desulfurization activity (100.0%), more biphenyls (31.3%) were produced during the reaction, and the desulfurization selectivity (HYD/DDS) was lower (only 1.8) than the catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g (6.5), which indicated that the Z5-NiMo-10 g was more inclined to hydrogenolysis pathway than others. Furthermore, the hydrodesulphurization activity of the catalyst are related to Lewis acid, and the stronger Lewis acid can produce higher hydro desulfurization activity [22]. The Py-IR results showed that the Lewis acid of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts modified by nanoclusters was obviously enhanced. In particular, the catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g has high Lewis acid content. It is also the reason for its higher hydrodesulphurization activity. 3.3 The structure of the sulfide active phase HRTEM was used to observe the change of the sulfide active phase to analyze the effect of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters on the active phase of unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst. Besides, the slab length and stacking layer number of MoS2 were counted. And the average slab length (LA) and stacking layer number (NA) of MoS2 were also calculated. Fig. 7 presents the HRTEM diagram of the sulfide unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts. As shown in the figure, the black stripes with a spacing of about 0.6 nm are found in the HRTEM diagrams of all samples, which can be attributed to the structure of the MoS2 crystal [45,46]. In addition, the stripes with a spacing of approximately 0.3 nm can also be found in the catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g, which can be attributed to the Ni3S2 crystal structure [47]. Efraín Altamirano et al. [48] found that MoS2 and Ni3S2 nanoparticles could be produced simultaneously by decomposition of "NiMoS" phase (NiMoS→Ni3S2+MoS2), and the nanoparticles of MoS2 and Ni3S2 were found in Z5-NiMo-10 g simultaneously, indicating that there are the "NiMoS" active phases in Z5-NiMo-10 g. Topsøe et al. [49] proposed that "NiMoS" phase played an important role in the hydrodesulfurization reaction of the catalyst, and the image of "NiMoS" phase had been detected by the advanced technique of scanning tunnel microscopy (STM). And they also found that the "NiMoS" active phase could produce higher hydrogenation activity than the MoS2 active phase. In addition, it was found that the "NiMoS" active phase could be divided into two types: NiMoS (I) and NiMoS (II), respectively. For the supported Ni-Mo catalyst, NiMoS (I) can easily be formed due to the strong interaction between the metal active phase and the support. For the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst, NiMoS (II) is the Main active phase, and NiMoS (II) has stronger hydrogenation activity than that of NiMoS (I). Furthermore, the hydrogenation activity of sulfided unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst is also related to the slab length and the stacking layer number of MoS2 [50]. The shorter slab length and the more stacking layer number can produce higher hydrogenation activity [51–53]. The statistical results of the slab length and stacking layer number of MoS2 crystal phase are shown in Figs. 8 and 9 . The slab length and stacking layer number of NiMo-1.5, Z5-NiMo-10 g, and Z5-NiMo-14 h are mainly 7–9 nm and 4–8 layers, while other catalysts are mainly 10–12 nm and 2–5 layers, which show that NiMo-1.5, Z5-NiMo-10 g, and Z5-NiMo-14 h have the shorter slab length and more stacking layer number. Besides, the average slab length and the average stacking layer number of all catalysts were also calculated, and the results are shown in Table 4 . As shown in Table 4, the catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g shows the shortest average slab length (7.8 nm) and the maximum average stacking layer number (5.7), indicating that the Z5-NiMo-10 g will have higher hydrogenation activity, which is consistent with the catalytic activity evaluation results (Table 2). The frequency (f Mo) of the side active phase (MoS2) was also calculated, the results are listed in Table 4. The catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g also shows the highest f Mo (0.15), indicating that the Z5-NiMo-10 g has more side angle active phase (MoS2). It is beneficial to improve the contact probability between the sulfur-containing impurities and the active sites of the catalyst, thus to improve the hydro desulfurization activity of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions The unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst was modified by the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters. BET and SEM results show that the introduction of the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters can obviously increase the specific surface area of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts, and the structure of modified catalysts can become more loose and porous. FT-IR results show that the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst precursor (ammonium nickel moly date) is easier to decompose into NiMoO4 structure after the introduction of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters. Py-IR results reveal that the Lewis acid site of all catalysts modified by the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters is obviously improved. DBT hydrodesulphurization results reveal that the Z5-NiMo-10 g achieves the higher hydrogenation activity (a DBT desulfurization rate of 98.1% and an isomerization rate of 68.9%) due to more dispersed structure and suitable acidity. coredata.dc:description: The influence of ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters on the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst was investigated by correlating their physicochemical properties with the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) activity of dibenzothiophene (DBT). The physicochemical properties of the catalysts before and after modification were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, SEM, FT-IR, H2-TPR, Py-IR, and HRTEM techniques. Results showed that the specific surface area and Lewis acid of the unsupported Ni-Mo catalyst were improved obviously after modification, which indicate that the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters were successfully introduced into the unsupported Ni-Mo catalysts. Besides, DBT HDS results revealed that the catalysts Z5-NiMo-10 g and Z5-NiMo-14h exhibited high hydrodesulfurization activity (the desulfurization rate of 98.1% and 100.0%, respectively). In particular, the catalyst Z5-NiMo-10 g produced the highest isomerization rate of 68.9% due to more dispersed structure and suitable acidity.
coredata.dc:title: Study on the modification of unsupported hydrodesulfurization catalysts by the ZSM-5 zeolite nanoclusters
